newsitem.title: UK: Eurobond trade ideas -Sell World Bank yen and lira.
newsitem.headline: Eurobond trade ideas -Sell World Bank yen and lira.

text.p: Bond analysts' latest trade ideas seen in Eurosterling include the recommendation to buy B.A.T's 8.50 percent bond due 2005.
Societe Generale said the market has over-reacted to a recent lawsuit and that over time the spread would tighten.
A rally in Euroyen sees IBJ International suggesting a move out of the 5.25 percent World Bank bond due 2002 and the 4.75 percent World Bank bond due 2004.
IBJ said the rally had made World Bank globals expensive and the market topping out would be a good time to switch.
** Following are latest trade ideas, compiled by Reuters** EUROLIRE

STRATEGY The buy side of this switch is trading cheaper against the swap at 27 basis points through, compared with the sell side which is expensive at 41 b.p. through. The 10.40 percent Eurofima bond also offers around 18 b.p. more in yield.
STRATEGY PSK is expensive against the swap compared with GECC. GECC also gives around a 14 b.p. pick-up in yield and is trading cheaply against the BTP at about 15 b.p. through.
STRATEGY Eurofima is cheap at only around 16 b.p. through the swap and 12 b.p. through the BTP, offers around an 18 b.p. pick-up in yield and trades below par.
STRATEGY These bonds are all trading at attractive levels to the swap and BTP.
Some curve steepening is possible in the coming weeks.
STRATEGY The Swedish bond has not been fully absorbed by Japanese retail due to its size and has found its way back to the mainstream market.
Its current spread at nine b.p. over Treasuries and 15 b.p. over the curve the bond institutional appeal and its coupon makes it attractive to retail.
The Spain and Belgium bonds are trading closer to the curve.
To follow are a series of trades that exploit historically attractive opportunities to pick up yield.
STRATEGY Long-dated benchmark World Bank globals have become expensive due to the market's rally. With the market topping out it would be a good time to move out of these World Bank bonds.

STRATEGY The lawsuit against Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corp., a unit of B.A.T, is expected to be overturned on appeal. The market initially over-reacted and the spread on the B.A.T bond widened out by eight b.p. It has now started to tighten and is expected to come back to 54 b.p. over.
